### Problem 1 ()

In a greenhouse experiment, 5 types of light were used: natural, white, green, blue, and yellow. Eight tobacco plants, each 10 mm tall, were subjected to each type of light with the following means and variances of stem growths (in mm).

|  Color | Natural | White | Yellow | Blue | Green |
|   ---- |    ---  |  ---  |  ----  | ---- | ----  |
|  Mean  | 4.09    |4.30   |3.55    |3.01  |3.19   |
|Variance| 0.027   |0.083  |0.066   |0.030 |0.073  |

A partial ANOVA table was found to be

|Source of Variance|Sum of Squares (SS)|Degrees of Freedom (df)|Mean Squares (MS)|F test statistic $F_0$|
| ---  | ---  | --- | --- | --- |
|Treatment(Between or Model)| | |$a-1$| |
|Error(Within)|    | | |   
|Total|   |      | |

  (a) Complete the ANOVA table assuming the one-way fixed effects ANOVA model. Show main steps of your work. Keep 3 decimal places in $SS_Trt$

 --- 

  (b) Compute the standard error of the difference of two observed treatment means. (that is, compute $e(\bar y _{i.}-\bar y_{j.})$) Show main steps of your work.

### Problem 5 (3.22/26)

The response time in milliseconds was determined for three different types of circuits that could be used in an
automatic valve shutoff mechanism. The results from a completely randomized experiment are shown in the following table:

```{r echo=T}
table_circuit <- read_xlsx("Exercsie3_22.xlsx")
t.test(table_cellphone$TwentySeconds, table_cellphone$TenSeconds, paired = T,var.equal=T, alternative="greater", mu = 0, conf.level= 0.95)

```

  (a) Test the hypothesis that the three circuit types have the same response time. Use ð›¼ = 0.01.
  (b) Use Tukeyâ€™s test to compare pairs of treatment means. Use ð›¼ = 0.01.
  (d) Construct a set of orthogonal contrasts, assuming that at the outset of the experiment you suspected the
response time of circuit type 2 to be different from the other two.
  (e) If you were the design engineer and you wished to minimize the response time, which circuit type would you select?
  (f) Analyze the residuals from this experiment. Are the basic analysis of variance assumptions satisfied?
